text: I'm using the backtestloggingcontrol and saving lots of variables in the order notes. Is there a way to just save the market book instead? I've tried pickle and json but they can’t handle the datetimes. Thanks

text: For json, you can just output them as <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11875770/how-can-i-overcome-datetime-datetime-not-json-serializable|strings>. Or turn them in to <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19801727/convert-datetime-to-unix-timestamp-and-convert-it-back-in-python|unix timestamp>.

But there are some interesting "derived" ones, eg:
• "match rate"
• "queuing rate", rate at which bets are being offered (estimate)
• "cancelling rate", rate at which bets are cancelled (estimate)
But I bet I am missing something... hence why I asked...?

text: You I think were thinking the % of your offers matched which is hard to work out bur you can estimate based on the queue and cancel rates

text: Total matched / (total matched + total cancelled), no? Cancelled, with assumption of LAPSE

elements.text: Total matched / (total matched + total cancelled), no? Cancelled, with assumption of LAPSE

text:
yeah exactly, although "cancelled" is a bit of an estimate, as you can't exactly equate cancelled and newly queued, eg: over a 1 second period say:
• avail_t0sec = 500
• avail_t1sec = 400
• matched_in1sec = 80
So that could be in that period:
• 20 cancelled, 0 newly offered
• or 40 cancelled, 20 newly offered
etc....

elements.text: yeah exactly, although "cancelled" is a bit of an estimate, as you can't exactly equate cancelled and newly queued, eg: over a 1 second period say:

text: so you might as well combine that as one "derived" param: "newlyqueue_cancel"

text: If I put £100 up (make or take, arguably doesn’t matter), and £20 gets matched and £80 is cancelled because it lapses before it matches and the market goes to state where it can’t match (event start, market closes), that’s a 20% match. Iterate for all bets. I’m not sure how understanding queue dynamics helps to that number, it’s a trailing metric. Disagree?

text: so, i'm referring to steady state market, i.e pre-race, before "inplay" LAPSE

text: If you hold umnmatched and the price moves away from you, you have hit some EV (you think), but could not exploit for the £ you wanted. Now what? Move price? Wait? How urgent this question is could be determined by match rate. Big EV bets at 10% might not pay at the rate of slightly smaller EV at 95%…

text:
I honestly think that if you've got what it takes you can start from anywhere and just work until it works. Even if you start with something simple and apparently useless like WOM you can just push and push until you either get to the point where it works or you learn enough to move your understanding on.

If WOM was the only idea you had what could you do with it? Could you think of different ways to think about it or compose it? Or imagine all you had was WOM and you couldn't see anything else about the market - could you find a way to price the whole market based on just that? What would that look like?

Grinding out any idea however shit is far more likely to bring home the bacon than flitting from one superficially investigated idea to another in the hope that you strike gold on something that other people somehow haven't noticed.

That said, I don't think ANYONE can do it, most people can't do it, even most smart and seemingly qualified people can't do it, even if they try really hard. Somehow there are just people who can do it and people who can't. It's not the cleverest or the best or the hardest workers who succeed at this, it's just the people who can do it. So don't grind too hard or too long, if this doesn't work there are plenty of better things to do.

text:
Congrats on your success <@U01PJ5YMFBJ>, that's already far better than most people ever do. £2k a month is certainly useful and it puts you much higher up the pyramid than you might think.

Of the 2000 or so people on this slack there are really only a handful who are into the £millions and I'd bet my shoes that most members are lifetime losers. We have some very good players here and that's great, but I think sometimes the discussion can distort the expectations of newer players or people who are more recreational in their outlook. Tell a "normal" person that you're making £24k a year from gambling whilst you've got your feet up and they'll be blown away.

text: I like Michael's advice of sticking to something. I wish I'd done it in the past. However, a difficulty with that is working out how to dig deeper. It's not always clear how to take the correct step forwards

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I like Michael's advice of sticking to something. I wish I'd done it in the past. However, a difficulty with that is working out how to dig deeper. It's not always clear how to take the correct step forwards

text: Yeah I agree. One thing I like to do is just imagine that the thing I'm looking at is the only thing there was and then work through that as a kind of thought experiment.

elements.text: Yeah I agree. One thing I like to do is just imagine that the thing I'm looking at is the only thing there was and then work through that as a kind of thought experiment.

text:
I think I'd add that I don't think there is necessarily a "correct" step forwards, and in any case you don't always need to go forwards, I mean backwards isn't great but sideways might be good, at least it's not stasis. It's exploring.

I think if I told you the basis of my TPD betting (which I kind of want to but won't) you'd never believe that it would work but it does because I just pushed the idea even though it's basically quite stupid.
